utterances: There are those moments in life when we find ourselves saying something and realizing this was a piece of advice we had solidly rejected 10 years earlier.
Yeah.
Amtrak has been trying to put regional foods on its long-distance trains so that there is some sense of place.
And they had catfish on the City of New Orleans, for example.
You never looked at them?
Yes.
Yes.
As a child I thought, oh, well - in my younger years in school, she always would encourage me with something that I thought, oh, I can't - I'm not good in math.
And she would always - don't say you're not good.
We'll find someone who could help you if you're struggling in something, but there's nothing you can't do.
Just set your mind to it.
And, you know, she was just a very, very encouraging force.
And it was just amazing that she had all this wisdom, and yet she hadn't done a lot of the things that she was encouraging me to do.
And…
Well, it sounds like she helped raise nine kids.
That's challenging.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah.
It was - she was a great influence for all of us.
And me being the youngest, I could reflect back on every - what I saw all my older sisters and brothers going through.
And everyone became very successful.
I have a brother who's a college professor and another brother who's - was a teacher in the city school system, and my sister, who's a schoolteacher in the Baltimore City school system.
And so, we all, you know, did some positive things in our life.

And, you know, and it was all the result of - and although I don't have any memories of my mother, the older three, they do tell me - and my mother was the same way, and so they all have shared with me all of her, you know, wonderful attributes.
And, you know, I wish I had known her…
Yeah.
But, you know, I was just surrounded by a whole force of women.

And I just feel incredibly blessed that, you know, I was able to accomplish so much because, you know, I just feel like God put all of these wonderful people in my life, though my mother couldn't share, you know, the most of my life, you know, she - because she passed when I was very young, just a baby.
So…
Mitsy, thank you very much.
And we hope you'll remember her - obviously, you will - come Sunday on Mother's Day.
Amy, we just have a little time with you left.
And I wanted to ask the description Mitsy gave and so many others - indeed, you, too.
These people, these women who - well, you know, didn't accomplish that much in life.
Nonsense.
I know.
I know.
And look at the legacy that Mitsy's aunt gave to her and all of her siblings.
And I - you know, the role of aunts and sisters is just huge in anyone's life, if you're fortunate.
And I know - and look, what a grand accomplishment that woman did.
What a legacy she left.
Amy Dickinson…
Mm-hmm.
…thank you so much for being with us today.
Thank you, Neal.
And we'll put you back to work in a couple of weeks.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Okay.
Amy Dickinson writes the syndicated column ""Ask Amy,"" for the Chicago Tribune.
She's a regular guest on this program.
Her new book is titled ""The Mighty Queens of Freeville."" You can read an excerpt at our Web site, npr.org/talk.
And she joined us today from the studios of Chicago Public Radio.
Coming up, James Carville helped the governors, senators, presidents and prime ministers to big wins at the polls.
Today, he looks into his crystal ball at the future of the Democratic Party.
Let me go out on a limb.
I think he sees the glass as half-full.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.

You scarcely need reminders that gas prices are up, that airlines have cut flights, and destinations, and services, and raised ticket prices, so perhaps it's not surprising that more and more of us choose to travel by train.
Last year, Amtrak says it carried some 25 million passengers.
They're even busier so far this year.
Catherine Watson often rode the rails when she was travel editor of the Minneapolis Star Tribune, but rarely in this country.
Recently, she decided to try Amtrak on a trip from Minnesota to New Mexico, and wrote a story about it called ""Romance of the Rails"" that appeared last week in the San Francisco Chronicle.
You can find a link to her article on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Call and tell us why you travel by train, or not.
Our number is 800-989-8255.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
You can also join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
And Catherine Watson joins now from the studios of Minnesota Public Radio in St. Paul.
Nice to have you on Talk of the Nation today.
Nice to be here.
And why all that time without trying the rails in this country?
It never crossed my mind.
I had been traveling the way everybody else did, by air and - or car, and I was frustrated with that.
And a friend of mine a while back said - when I was going to come and visit her in New Mexico, I was angry because I couldn't get there fast, and couldn't get there easily.
And finally, I thought maybe I could drive, but gee, that's several days.
A long way, yeah.
She said, why don't you take the train?
And you said this just hasn't occurred to you, and yet...
It really hadn't.
You got to ride three of the most famous trains in American history.
Yes, I did, the Empire Builder down to Chicago, the City of New Orleans down to New Orleans from there, and the Sunset Limited West, which goes all the way to the coast, but I got off in El Paso.
And the trip, obviously, took, like driving, several days.
Several days, several days, but it was more fun.
It's nice not to be steering.
And you can talk to people.
It's just amazing.
People talk to people.
People had real conversations.
Kids run up and down in the aisles, because they weren't strapped in the seat and crying.
And people played cards.
People read.
You watched movies that Amtrak was showing.
The food was good.
Well, it's all very much up in the air.
There's been some movement in the Senate towards the President's position.
The committee in charge of the bill has moved towards the President's position, but there are a lot of other Republicans who don't want an amnesty or guest worker program.
So, the president's going to have to exert pressure.
The problem is his relations with Congress aren't very good, and Josh Bolten's not going to fix that.
Analysis and opinion from John Dickerson.
He's chief political correspondent for the online magazine Slate.
John, thanks for being with us again.
Thank you.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Andrea Seabrook in Washington.
This summer, thousands of high school juniors and seniors and their parents will crisscross the country, visiting colleges and universities.
For 25 years, perspective college students have turned to U.S.
News & World Report's Guide to America's Best Colleges for help.
The magazine compiles data from thousands of American schools on everything from selectivity, to how much money alumni give.
Now last week, administrators at many liberal arts colleges decided that the ranking system doesn't give students enough information or the right information.
Several dozen colleges have decided to withdraw from the U.S.
News & World Report rankings.
If you are applying to schools, how did you choose where to apply?
Are you starting college this fall?
How did you decide where to go?
Our number here in Washington is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
Our e-mail address is talk@npr.org.
You can comment on our blog, too, at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Later in the show, we'll talk about the science of gaydar.
But first, college admissions.
Kate Will is the president of Gettysburg College in Pennsylvania.
She's also the author and head, excuse me, she's also the head of the Annapolis Group, a consortium of 121 liberal arts colleges from around the country.
Kate Will joins us from our studio in Topeka, Kansas.
Thanks for coming in.
My pleasure.
Kate Will, let's start with a wide open question.
What criteria should students use to pick a college?
First of all, the student should think about match.
Does this college provide the things that are going to enable me to be a successful student, to really thrive and grow and learn during my four years there?
So I'd emphasize match, first of all.
And a match means that different schools are different - are better for different people.

So the reason we're concerned about the rankings is that it kind of implies that only the, you know, top 10 or the top 15 schools are good enough to go to and adds to a kind of admissions frenzy and anxiety amongst students and their families about which school to go to.
So we would encourage, the presidents of the Annapolis Group would encourage, students and families to take a good look at schools.
Think about what size of school they want.
Think about what kind of majors they're interested in, and then make sure that school has those majors.
Think about what the life outside the classroom is going to be like.
Definitely visit, that's really, really important to visit the college because so often, it's really a matter of feel and your gut reaction to the place and to the people there.
And that's the way you can tell that you're going to fit in.
And honestly, I would urge students to trust their instincts on this.
